awd_titl_txt: The YardMap Network: Social Networking for Community Science
awd_abstract_narration:
The Cornell Lab of Ornithology, the Institute for Learning Innovation, and several environmental organizations are merging existing bird-focused citizen science programs with gardening and online social networking activities to provide older adult learners (age 35 and up) with opportunities to investigate the environmental impacts of implementing landscaping and carbon-reducing practices in their backyards, community gardens, and parks. The YardMap Network project is developing learning resources that will help gardeners, birders, and novices learn bird-habitat improving and carbon-reducing living practices by joining a nationwide ecological social network composed of more than 100,000 people. The goal of the project is to create online learning communities that move people from basic and intermediate levels ecological understanding to advanced levels of understanding by providing experiences whereby YardMappers learn about, design, evaluate, share, and invent conservation practices in their backyards and other green spaces.

While developing the network, the project will gather data to test the hypothesis that coupling citizen science activities with social networking technologies to create online learning communities improves participants' understanding of project-relevant science, technology, engineering, and mathematics. The project will track learning outcomes using standard evaluation techniques and by following individuals' routes of entry, network interactions, mapped garden practices, carbon-neutral behaviors, and their bird monitoring activities. YardMappers will divide naturally into treatment groups, creating a quasi-experimental design to test the importance of social networking for basic, intermediate, and advanced learning outcomes.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Cornell Univ - State: AWDS MADE PRIOR MAY 2010

por.por_cntn:
The YardMap Network focused on how to design citizen science environments that enable people to learn, implement, and share scientifically-informed, environmental stewardship practices that can be carried out in living and working landscapes.  Although funded as a learning system, it has also been recognized as a new kind of technology for collecting and analyzing data on coupled human and natural systems. YardMap seeks to support learning in the rich domain of environmental science and is designed to move beyond species identification and natural history observation by asking people to explore ecological principles and learn about the complex nature of their role as part of the earth system. It also seeks to test and improve user interface designs that support learning through mapping, social networking, and group membership. During the course of the grant, the team designed, built and revised the YardMap network tool, which continues to grow in size and reach. By the end of the grant, 17,740 participants had made maps and well over 323,000 unique visitors used the learning resources, which do not require sign-in. The summative evaluation was conducted from April-July of 2014, and compared people who participated in YardMap with those who were allocated to a waitlist control - which meant that they waited to participate until after taking the postsurvey, 6 after they took the pre-survey.  During the six weeks they had access to readings, but did not participate in the mapping activities.

Participants did not learn more about plants or birds by participating in mapping, which may reflect the fact that we didn't provide content or encourage reading about these topics. We predicted that the social network to foster this kind of learning. As the social network was not active enough to promote social learning on its own, it was not surprising that this kind of learning was not supported. On the other hand, conceptual learning appeared to increase as a function of mapping; people who mapped reported that they had begun to think differently about their yards as habitat for birds.

Since the summative evaluation, YardMap has continued to grow exponentially and we have produced new and richer content focusing on the conceptual and practical issues related to residential conservation practices. The Project Leader writes regularly about YardMap for Houzz, garnering 60,000 readers per month. The team has embarked on important partnerships, including a new partnership with The Nature Conservancy (through a private gift sought jointly to improve the tool and blast communications about the activity to a much larger audience). Researchers at Washington State University have included YardMap in their "A-Bird" grant from the USDA to support an alliance of academics and Non-governmental organizations focused on bird-friendly farming. The new groups tool has begun to support an interesting and varied set of entities and new NSF funding has been secured to study learning as a function of activity and interaction within and between groups. As we move forward, we expect to see YardMap emerge as an informative test case of how to combine citizen science with the development of human computation systems to better manage coupled human and natural systems. New approaches, including A/B testing, should expedite improvement of the user experience and understanding of how application design influences learning outcomes.


Last Modified: 02/11/2016
Modified by: Janis L Dickinson
